about.title: About the project
about.description: Learn more about the "Look at the Stars" project, our team, and the homemade astronomical observatory. Join us and discover the beauty of space!
about.intro: , and this site is my attempt to tell you about my hobby, bring together all the information, and capture the achievements made on the way to exploring space. Astronomy for me is not just a passion, but a whole world that changed my life. Thanks to it, I found incredible friends, learned a lot, and realized how vast and mysterious the universe is. This project is our joint contribution to the popularization and development of astronomy. We sincerely believe that thanks to our efforts, space will become closer and more accessible to everyone.
about.telegram-channel: Subscribe to the author's Telegram channel of this project
about.team-description: We work in various fields, but we are all united by one thing — love for the stars and the night sky. Since 2016, we have been popularizing astronomy, organizing stargazing trips in the Orenburg region and sidewalk astronomy evenings in Orenburg. Together we look at the stars, share knowledge, and inspire others.
about.project-description: In 2016, we launched the "Look at the Stars" project in the Orenburg region to make astronomy accessible to everyone. Since then, every season we hold free lectures under the open sky, organize trips out of town with telescopes, and host informal sidewalk astronomy evenings.
about.project-goal: The main goal of the project is to show the greatness and beauty of the universe, to inspire people to study space. We cover not only the Orenburg region but also neighboring regions, traveling to places where the night sky is especially bright. Learn more about our current and past events on the page
about.project-sidewalk: , and for those who want to see the stars in the city, we have prepared a section
about.project-sidewalk-link: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg
about.project-locations: Our events are held not only in cities and towns of the Orenburg region but also in neighboring regions. We organize excursions to remote places where minimal light pollution allows you to fully enjoy the starry sky. Our team of amateur astronomers and volunteers shares their knowledge and experience so that everyone can discover the beauty and mysteries of the universe.
about.project-lectures: One of the most important parts of the project are lectures given by experienced amateur astronomers. We talk about scientific discoveries, the history of astronomy, and its modern achievements. The lectures are held in an easy format, where complex things are explained in simple and understandable language. This helps listeners not only broaden their horizons but also inspires independent study of astronomy.
about.project-sidewalk-astronomy: We pay special attention to sidewalk astronomy evenings. These meetings under the open sky are held in the most accessible places in the city. At such events, anyone can come up, look through a telescope, and learn more about what the starry sky hides.
about.observatory-intro: This project is one of the most significant stages of my life. Our homemade astronomical observatory is a unique phenomenon for the Orenburg region. It operates autonomously and allows you to obtain images of deep space objects, making astronomy accessible to everyone. You can learn more about the observatory's operation and equipment in the section -

observatory-work-1.text: The observatory is open to everyone. Anyone can use its capabilities to obtain images of space objects. Moreover, the site has a section

about.observatory-work-2: , where you will find an archive of FITS files. These data can be used for training, asteroid search, astrophotography, and other scientific or creative purposes.
about.observatory-photos-1: Soon we will launch a free telescope control service so that even more people can join the beauty of the night sky. Don't forget to check out the section
about.observatory-photos-2: , where you will find images taken with the observatory and during our stargazing trips. These photos are processed by me and my friends and reflect our passion for space.
about.observatory-conclusion: This project is our contribution to the popularization of astronomy. We sincerely hope it will inspire you to discover the universe!
about.your-help-intro: The development of the "Look at the Stars" project has largely become possible thanks to the support of the "Native Cities" social investment program of Gazprom Neft and the assistance of the Orenburg Media information agency team.
about.your-help-description: Our homemade observatory project has also found a response among many caring participants. We have ambitious plans for the development of this direction, and your support plays a key role. We are grateful to everyone who helps with advice, consultations, and recommendations. If we accidentally missed someone in the list of thanks, write to us — it is very important.
about.your-help-conclusion: Thanks to your help, space really becomes closer!

observatory.title: Observatory
observatory.description: Homemade amateur astronomical observatory with remote access from anywhere in the world via the Internet. Observatory statistics, number of frames taken, and accumulated data. Telescope work calendar.
observatory.text: Observing the universe starts here - in real time you can see current weather conditions, camera streams, equipment status, and shooting schedule. The observatory operates in semi-automatic mode, allowing remote deep-sky imaging. An intelligent control system analyzes weather conditions and automatically decides when to start work. Learn more about the equipment and operation on a separate page:

mount.title: Mount: Sky-Watcher EQ6
mount.description: Reliable and accurate mount providing telescope stability even during long exposures.

telescope.title: Telescope: Sky-Watcher BK2001P
telescope.description: Reflector telescope with a 200 mm aperture, ideal for deep space observations.

main-camera.title: Main camera: ASI ZWO 6200MM Pro
main-camera.description: High-sensitivity astronomical camera with 24 MP resolution, capable of capturing the smallest details of distant objects.

guide-camera.title: Guide camera: QHY QHY5
guide-camera.description: Camera for precise guiding and tracking of objects.

guide-scope.title: Guide scope: SV106 Guide Scope 50mm (Helical Focuser)
guide-scope.description: Compact telescope for guiding during long exposures.

focuser.title: Focuser: ZWO EAF
focuser.description: Electronic focuser for precise focus adjustment.

filter-wheel.title: Filter wheel: ZWO EFW 8x31mm
filter-wheel.description: Universal filter wheel for working with various spectral ranges.

filters.title: Filters: ZWO L, R, G, B, Ha, OIII, SII (1.25")
filters.description: Set of filters for color imaging and narrowband shooting.

coma-corrector.title: Coma corrector: Baader 2" Mark III MPCC
coma-corrector.description: Eliminates optical distortions, ensuring image sharpness.

observatory.description-1: The main activity of the observatory is photographing deep-sky objects such as nebulae, galaxies, and star clusters. The equipment and technologies used allow for high-quality images suitable for scientific research and educational purposes.
observatory.description-2: The observatory operates in semi-automatic mode, allowing remote control from anywhere in the world via the Internet. This makes it accessible to amateur astronomers, researchers, and enthusiasts worldwide.
observatory.description-3: The observatory is open for collaboration with amateur astronomers, researchers, and educational institutions. We are happy to provide access to our data for scientific and educational purposes. If you want to join our community or use our resources for your projects, contact us via the feedback form.
observatory.description-4: Orenburg Observatory is a unique combination of modern technology and the enthusiasm of amateur astronomers. We strive to make astronomy accessible to everyone interested in the mysteries of the universe. Join us to explore the vastness of space together!
observatory.equipment-description: The tools and technologies used ensure high observation accuracy and professional image quality. Here is the main equipment used:

For each object, detailed parameters and characteristics are available, such as distance, size, spectral data, and much more. These materials can be useful for both beginner astronomers and professionals.

stargazing.title: Stargazing
stargazing.where_link: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg
stargazing.description: Stargazing in Orenburg — exciting trips out of town where telescopes open cosmic horizons. Evenings of scientific discoveries, lectures, and live communication with like-minded people. Learn the rules and prepare for star observation.
stargazing.telegram-subscription: To not miss announcements, subscribe to the Telegram channel
stargazing.text-part-1: Stargazing in Orenburg is an opportunity to touch the mysteries of the universe, observing the starry sky in complete darkness. We invite you to exciting trips out of town, where telescopes open cosmic horizons right in the fields of Orenburg.
stargazing.text-part-2: Each stargazing event is an evening of scientific discoveries, inspiring lectures, and live communication with like-minded people. You will learn how our events are held, get acquainted with the main rules, and prepare for star observation.

stargazing-faq.title: Frequently asked questions
stargazing-faq.description: Find answers to common questions about stargazing: registration, what to bring, cost, duration, and how to get there. Prepare for a night under the stars with comfort!

where.question: ❓How to find out where it takes place?
where.answer: Our stargazing events are always held out of town, usually within 40-70 km. We leave the city lights to see the stars. The exact location is available after registration. If you lost the location, return to the registration page via the same link. There is geolocation - Yandex.Map and Google.Map.

registration.question: ❓Can I come without registration?
registration.answer: No, you can't. Registration is required as it allows us to plan the event, notify participants of changes, and ensure comfort for everyone.

qr.question: ❓Why do I need a QR code?
qr.answer: The QR code is your entry ticket to our event. It will be checked at the entrance. Please prepare it in advance to avoid traffic jams. If you don't have a QR code, we will have to refuse you. The QR code helps us regulate the number of participants at the site. Our natural landscape and team capacity have limits. Please respect this.

what-to-bring.question: ❓What to bring?
what-to-bring.answer: For comfort at the site, be sure to have warm clothes (we are in the steppe, it's windy and cold at night), a camping mat, folding chairs, blankets. We also recommend thermoses with tea/coffee and sandwiches. Take insect repellent. Hookahs, barbecues, alcohol, cigarettes are prohibited! Our site is the cleanest. After stargazing, we don't find any litter and thank you for that!

no-car.question: ❓I don't have a car, what should I do?
no-car.answer: We do not organize transport. Our task is to organize a great event, yours is to get there. For your convenience, we created a chat
no-car.answer2: . Join, meet people, and find company. Everyone there is cool, sociable, and reliable. Want to chat about space? Join the themed

public-transport.question: ❓Can I get to the stargazing site by public transport?
public-transport.answer: Unfortunately, no. The site is far from public transport routes. You can get there by car or join other participants if they can take you. We recommend arranging this in advance via our Telegram channel.

start-time.question: ❓What time does it start?
start-time.answer: Each stargazing announcement has a specific start time. This time it's 21:30. Gathering on site is from 20:00 to 21:00. Please arrive early — listen to music, take photos with the Moon and sunflowers, watch sunsets, breathe the steppe air. And importantly, park your car and avoid traffic jams. We appreciate it!

price.question: ❓How much does it cost?
price.answer: All our stargazing events are free. The project grows and develops, and we always appreciate support from listeners and subscribers. For this, there are
price.answer2: . If you want to support us, we will be grateful!

duration.question: ❓How long does stargazing last?
duration.answer: The official program from the start of the lecture to telescope observations lasts about 2 hours. But time flies by, guaranteed. After that, you choose — stay and watch the sky or go home. Approximate end time: 00:30.

weather.question: ❓What if it's cloudy or rainy?
weather.answer: If the weather forecast is unfavorable (clouds or precipitation), the event may be canceled or postponed. We always notify participants of such changes via our Telegram channel, so follow updates.

telescopes.question: ❓Do I need to bring my own telescope?
telescopes.answer: No, it's not necessary. We always have several telescopes for general use. If you have your own, you can bring it, and our experts will help you set it up.

kids.question: ❓Can children come?
kids.answer: Yes, and they should! We are very happy when the younger generation is interested in science! Recommended age is 6 and up. Trust our experience.

photo.question: ❓Can I take photos?
photo.answer: Of course! You can take photos, but please follow etiquette so as not to disturb others. Don't use bright flashes or lights, as this can spoil night observation.

merch.question: ❓How and where to buy your merch?
merch.answer: We bring hoodies, t-shirts, car stickers, postcards, and sticker packs to the site. Want to support the project — buy our merch!

cancel.question: ❓I registered but can't come. What should I do?
cancel.answer: Just cancel your booking via the previous link. Free slots will appear on the site and others can register.

more-people.question: ❓I registered 1\2\3\4\5 people, can I bring more?
more-people.answer: No, you can't. Our rules are the same for everyone. The QR code allows entry for the number of people you registered. No exceptions.

late-registration.question: ❓Registration is closed and I didn't make it. Can I come? Please!
late-registration.answer: No, sorry. Our rules are the same for everyone. We introduced registration for a reason and monitor entry to the site.

support.question: ❓I like you! How can I support you?
support.answer2: . We constantly buy equipment, update technical capabilities, create merch and activities. Your support is ❤︎❤︎❤︎

feedback.question: ❓Where can I leave feedback?
feedback.answer: In all social networks our group is called "Look at the Stars". We value feedback and always read your reviews. Thank you!

stargazing-howto.title: How stargazing works
stargazing-howto.description: Learn how stargazing events are held in Orenburg: registration, space lectures, telescope observations, and learning to navigate the starry sky. Subscribe to the "Look at the Stars" Telegram channel and join unique astronomy events under the starry sky!
stargazing-howto.unique_event: Each stargazing event is unique, but we follow a general scenario to make it interesting and convenient for all participants.
stargazing-howto.event_announcement_text: Stargazing events in Orenburg are held in good weather, so the exact date is known only 2-3 days before. We announce upcoming trips in our Telegram channel "Look at the Stars", where we post announcements and important updates. Subscription is required so you don't miss a new stargazing event.
stargazing-howto.registration_text: To participate, you need to register in advance on our website. It's free and takes just a minute. Beware of scammers — if someone asks for payment, it's a scam! We welcome donations, but participation is always free.
stargazing-howto.location_text: Stargazing events are held out of town, away from city lights, usually 40 km from Orenburg. The exact location is revealed after registration. Get there on your own, so check the route in advance. The last section is a dirt road about 300 meters long.
stargazing-howto.arrival_text: Arrive 15–20 minutes early to get a good spot. Bring folding chairs or mats for comfort.
stargazing-howto.lecture_text: As dusk falls, our astronomy lecture begins. On a big screen, we show videos and photos, talking about space in an accessible and interesting way. Topics vary: from "Perseid meteor shower" to "What do black holes hide". Lectures are for ages 8+ and last about an hour.
stargazing-howto.orientation_text: After the lecture, we teach you to find main stars and constellations, showing them in the sky. This part lasts about 20 minutes.
stargazing-howto.telescope_observation_text: Several telescopes are set up, each aimed at specific space objects. You can look through telescopes, ask questions, and talk to astronomers.
stargazing-howto.event_duration_text: The whole stargazing event lasts 2 to 4 hours. You can leave anytime, but many stay until the end, enjoying the starry sky.
stargazing-howto.recommendations_text: Please read the "Stargazing rules" section to make the event comfortable and safe for everyone.
stargazing-howto.thematic_evenings_text: Sometimes we hold sidewalk astronomy right in the city. Details about such events are in the "Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg" section.
stargazing-howto.faq: Didn't find your answer? Check the
stargazing-howto.telegram: or write in our Telegram channel

stargazing-rules.title: Stargazing rules
stargazing-rules.description: Learn the rules for stargazing in Orenburg: what not to do when observing stars and planets through a telescope. Follow recommendations for a safe and comfortable event.
stargazing-rules.welcome: Welcome to stargazing in Orenburg, organized by the "Look at the Stars" project! To make joint observation of the starry sky and planets comfortable and safe for everyone, it's important to follow a few simple rules. These recommendations help preserve the atmosphere and ensure everyone enjoys the view.
stargazing-rules.prohibited-title: What not to do at stargazing events

prohibited-items-1.title: Use bright light sources
prohibited-items-1.description: Flashlights, phone screens, and any bright devices disrupt eye adaptation to darkness, reducing visibility. Use only red flashlights or special filters.

prohibited-items-2.title: Light fires and use open flames
prohibited-items-2.description: Stargazing is held in fields and open areas with high fire risk. Lighting fires is strictly prohibited.

prohibited-items-3.title: Drink alcohol and smoke
prohibited-items-3.description: Alcohol, cigarettes, e-cigarettes, vapes, and hookahs are prohibited. This is not only about fire safety but also respect for others who value clean air and a clear night sky.

prohibited-items-4.title: Make noise and disturb others
prohibited-items-4.description: Loud music, shouting, or other noises can distract and interfere with telescope observation. Respect the silence and mood of others.

recommendations-items-1.title: Protect nature
recommendations-items-1.description: Take all your trash with you after observation. We try to leave stargazing sites as clean as they were before.

recommendations-items-2.title: Follow safety rules
recommendations-items-2.description: Move carefully to avoid damaging equipment or hurting yourself.

recommendations-items-3.title: Respect other participants
recommendations-items-3.description: Everyone came to enjoy the beauty of space. Respectful attitude makes the atmosphere friendly and comfortable.

stargazing-rules.importance-title: Why is it important to follow the rules?
stargazing-rules.importance-description: Following these recommendations makes stargazing in Orenburg comfortable for everyone. We create an atmosphere where everyone can see amazing celestial phenomena, study planets through a telescope, and have an unforgettable experience.
stargazing-rules.join-description: Want to know more about our events in Orenburg?

stargazing-where.title: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg
stargazing-where.description: Find out where in Orenburg you can look through a telescope. Sidewalk astronomy: free observations of the Moon, planets, and stars on city streets. Want to see more — go out of town for nebulae and galaxies!
stargazing-where.intro: Sidewalk astronomy is a unique format that brings space closer. In spring, summer, and autumn, we set up telescopes right on the sidewalks and squares of Orenburg so anyone can look at stars, planets, and the Moon for free. It's a great opportunity for city residents to get to know astronomy in a relaxed and friendly atmosphere.
stargazing-where.announcement-1: We almost always post announcements of sidewalk astronomy evenings in our
stargazing-where.announcement-2: , but sometimes you can find our telescopes on the streets without warning. One of the project inspirers, astronomy lecturer Vladimir Ivanovich, often shares his knowledge, showing interesting objects to everyone. Just look for the telescope — and you'll get an unforgettable tour of the starry sky!
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-title: What can you see through a telescope in the city?
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-description: With city light pollution, the brightest objects remain visible. For example, you can see:
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-1: Craters and mountains on the Moon, especially impressive in the first and last quarters;
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-3: Bright stars and double stars, such as Albireo;
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-4: Planet parades, if they occur at the right time of year.
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-conclusion: However, city lights limit our possibilities. Nebulae, galaxies, meteor showers, and even large star clusters are often hidden.
stargazing-where.want-to-see-more: Want to see more? Go out of town!
stargazing-where.want-to-see-description-1: To observe faint objects like the Orion Nebula, Andromeda, meteor showers, and star clusters, you need to get away from city lights. In places like the Orenburg steppe or other remote areas, the night sky is stunning.
stargazing-where.want-to-see-description-2: We regularly organize out-of-town astronomy events where you can enjoy the full palette of cosmic objects. Follow announcements on our "Stargazing" page or Telegram channel to join one.

star-map.title: Star map
star-map.description: Star map with galaxies, nebulae, comets, supernovae, and other space objects photographed with an amateur telescope
star-map.text-part-1: The star map is an interactive window into the universe, featuring images of galaxies, nebulae, comets, supernovae, and other astronomical objects. These images were taken with an amateur telescope, making them especially valuable: they show what beauties of space are available even outside professional observatories.
star-map.text-part-2: The map allows you to study the night sky in detail, track the movement of celestial bodies, and find interesting objects for observation. Thanks to high-quality astrophotography and regular catalog updates, every visitor can see space as astronomy enthusiasts around the world do.
